what.heading: What is CORS?
what.description: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a security feature implemented by web browsers that restricts web pages from making requests to a different domain than the one serving the page. This prevents malicious websites from accessing sensitive data.

how.heading: How CORS Works
how.description: When your web application tries to access a resource from a different origin, the browser sends a preflight OPTIONS request to check if the server allows the cross-origin request. The server responds with CORS headers that specify which origins, methods, and headers are allowed.

common.heading: Common CORS Issues
common.missing: Missing CORS headers - server doesn't include Access-Control-Allow-Origin
common.wrong_origin: Wrong origin - server allows different origins than yours
common.credentials: Credentials issues - trying to send cookies without proper headers
common.methods: Method not allowed - the HTTP method you're using isn't permitted
